case_name: S. G. Jaisinghani v. Union of India

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1038 of 1965 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated March 11, 1964 of the Punjab High Court in Civil Writ Petition No. 189-D of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated the March 11, 1964 of the Punjab High Court, Circuit Bench at Delhi in Civil Writ Petition No. 189-D of 1962.

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 5 of 1966 is a petition under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: AND WRIT PETITION No. 5 OF 1966. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India- for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: The appellant S. G. Jaisinghani filed a writ petition under Article 226 challenging the constitutional validity of the seniority rule for Income-tax Service, Class I, Grade II.

anchor.surface_text: In his petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution, the appellant, S. G. Jaisinghani, challenged the constitutional validity of what has been described as the seniority rule in regard to Income-tax Service, Class 1, Grade 11

facts.text: Government of India reconstituted Income-Tax Services as Class I and II on September 29, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: In order to improve the Income Tax administration the Government of India, on September 29, 1944, reconstituted and classified the existing Income-Tax Services as Class I and 11.

facts.text: Recruitment to Income-Tax Officers, Class I Grade II Service was partly by promotion and partly by direct recruitment in 80:20 ratio.

anchor.surface_text: The re-organisational scheme provided for recruitment of Income-Tax Officers, Class I Grade 11 Service partly by promotion and partly by direct recruitment.

facts.text: Rules of seniority laid down in Government of India letter dated January 24, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In Government of India, Ministry of Finance  Revenue Division  letter dated January 24, 1950  Ex. G to the writ petition , the rules of seniority were laid down.

facts.text: Seniority rules revised on September 5, 1952 by Government of India letter No. F. No. 58 3 -Ad. IT150.

anchor.surface_text: These rules were revised on September 5, 1952 by the Government of India, Ministry of Finance, Revenue Division, letter No. F. No. 58 3 -Ad. IT150, dated September 5, 1952.

facts.text: Recruitment quotas revised on October 18, 1951 to 66-2/3% direct recruitment and 33-1/3% by promotion.

anchor.surface_text: On October 18, 1951 the recruitment quotas of 80/ and 20 under the re-organisation scheme dated September 29, 1944 were revised. Under the revised recruitment quota rule 66- 2/3 of the vacancies

facts.text: Punjab High Court Full Bench dismissed the writ petition holding seniority rules not discriminatory.

anchor.surface_text: The Full Bench of the Punjab High Court rejected the writ petition of the appellant holding that the principles for determining seniority between direct recruits and promotees laid down in rule 1 f  iii  and  iv , 1952 were number discriminatory

facts.text: High Court held quota rule is merely policy statement without statutory force.

anchor.surface_text: It was also decided by the Full Bench that the quota rule announced by the Government of India was merely a policy statement and had numberstatutory force and departure from the quota did number give rise to any, justiciable issue.

facts.text: Appellant contended excessive recruitment of promotees violating quota: 71 excess from 1951-1956.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant, there was excessive recruitment of 71 promotees more than the figure permitted by the quota rule.

facts.text: High Court found excess promotees of 31 for years 1951-1954.

anchor.surface_text: In the judgment under appeal the High Court has examined the matter and found that the excess number of promotees was 31 for the four years 1951 to 1954.

facts.text: Supreme Court held seniority rule 1(f)(iii) of 1952 valid and not violating Articles 14 and 16.

anchor.surface_text: The first question to be companysidered in this appeal is whether rule 1 f  iii  of the seniority rules as framed in 1952 violates the guarantee under Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court held quota rule has statutory force under Rule 4 of Recruitment Rules and must be followed.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the argument of the Solicitor-General that the quota rule was- number legally binding on the Government. It is number-disputed that rule 4 of the- Income-tax Officers

facts.text: Promotees in excess of quota from 1951-1956 illegally promoted; order to adjust seniority.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that promotees from Class II, Grade III to Class 1, Grade II Service in excess of the prescribed quotas for each of the years 1951 to 1956 and onwards have been illegally promoted

facts.text: Direct recruits undergo 2 years probation in Class I Grade II.

anchor.surface_text: A Class 11 Officer when directly recruited had to be on pro- bation for two years during which period he had to undergo a companyrse of theoretical and practical training

facts.text: Promotees have minimum 5 years service in Class II before consideration for Class I Grade II.

anchor.surface_text: After a minimum period of thee years of work as Income-tax Officer  after his probation of two yea rs  he is companysidered by the Departmental Promotion Committee for promotion to Class 1.

facts.text: Respondents 4,5,6 appointed to Class II Grade III in 1947, to Class I Grade II in 1951 after competitive exam 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to rule 1 f  iv  of the Seniority Rules, there are only three respondents i.e., respondents 4, 5 and 6 who have been promoted as deemed promotees under this clause of the rule.

facts.text: Appellant S.G. Jaisinghani successful in competitive exam 1950, joined Class I Grade II in 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Each one of them was appointed in Class 11, Grade III Service in 1947 and was appointed in Class 1, Grade II Service in 1951 after having successfully companypeted in the companypetitive examination of the year 1950, the same year in which the appellant was successful.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal in part and granted mandamus for seniority adjustment.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we allow this appeal in part and order that a writ in the nature of Mandamus should be granted to the appellant to the extent indicated above.

facts.text: Writ Petition No.5/1966 allowed for similar reasons.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given in that case, we hold that this petition should be allowed and a writ in the nature of mandamus under Art. 32 of the Constitution should be granted

holdings.text: We are unable to accept the contention of the appellant as correct. In our opinion, it is not right to approach this problem as if it is a case of classification of one service into two classes for the purpose of promotion, and as the promotion rule operation to the disadvantage of one of the two classes.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the contention of the appellant as correct. In our opinion, it is not right to approach this problem as if it is a case of classification of one service into two classes for the purpose of promotion, and as the promotion rule operation to the disadvantage of one of the two classes. It is really a case of recruitment to the Service from two different sources and then adjustment of seniority between the recruits coming from the two sources.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Recruitment from different sources (direct vs promotion) justifies classification for seniority; promotees have prior experience equivalent to probation; linked to quota; cites Rangachari precedent on Art 16 scope.

holdings.text: In our opinion, there is no substance in the contention of the appellant. Once it is held that the rule of seniority enacted in rule 1 f iii is legally valid, the rule of promotion i.e., rule 4 of Ch. IX of the Central Board of Revenue Office Procedure Manual cannot be held to lead to any discrimination as between direct recruits and promotees.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no substance in the contention of the appellant. Once it is held that the rule of seniority enacted in rule 1 f iii is legally valid, the rule of promotion i.e., rule 4 of Ch. IX of the Central Board of Revenue Office Procedure Manual cannot be held to lead to any discrimination as between direct recruits and promotees. Rule 4 states that the prescribed minimum service for Class 1, Grade 11 Officer in the matter of promotion to Grade I of that Service is five years gazetted service including one year in Class 1, Grade 11.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Promotion rule implements valid seniority rule by counting prior Class II service for promotees to avoid nullifying seniority weightage; no discrimination.

holdings.text: We are accordingly of the opinion that rule 1 f iv is based on a reasonable classification and does not offend the guarantee under Art. 14 or Art. 16 1 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that rule 1 f iv is based on a reasonable classification and does not offend the guarantee under Art. 14 or Art. 16 1 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deemed promotee status for Class II officers passing competitive exam reasonable; incentivizes exam, accounts for prior service; they would be senior anyway via promotion.

holdings.text: We are unable to accept the argument of the Solicitor-General that the quota rule was not legally binding on the Government. It is not disputed that rule 4 of the Income-tax Officers (Class 1, Grade II) Service Recruitment Rules is a statutory rule.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the argument of the Solicitor-General that the quota rule was- number legally binding on the Government. It is number-disputed that rule 4 of the- Income-tax Officers (Class 1, Grade II) Service Recruitment Rules is a statutory rule and there is a statutory duty cast on the Government under this rule to, determine the method or methods to be employed for the purpose of filling the vacancies and. the number of candidates to be recruited by each method.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quota fixed under statutory Rule 4 is binding; no arbitrary deviation; linked to seniority rule validity.

holdings.text: We are accordingly of the opinion that promotees from Class II, Grade III to Class 1, Grade II Service in excess of the prescribed quotas for each of the years 1951 to 1956 and onwards have been illegally promoted and the appellant is entitled to a writ in the nature of mandamus commanding respondents 1 to 3 to adjust the seniority...

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that promotees from Class II, Grade III to Class 1, Grade II Service in excess of the prescribed quotas for each of the years 1951 to 1956 and onwards have been illegally promoted and the appellant is entitled to a writ in the nature of mandamus commanding respondents I to 3 to adjust the seniority of the appellant and other officers similarly placed like him and to prepare a fresh seniority list in accordance with law after adjusting the recruitment for the period 1951 to 1956 and onwards in accordance with the quota rule prescribed in the letter of the Government of India No. F. 24 2 -Admn. I.T./51 dated October 18, 1951.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Excess over quota violates binding rule; requires adjustment of seniority lists excluding excess promotees; mandamus to enforce statutory duty.

holdings.text: For the reasons given in that case, we hold that this petition should be allowed and a writ in the nature of mandamus under Art. 32 of the Constitution should be granted commanding respondents 1 to 3 to adjust the seniority of the petitioner and other officers similarly placed like him and to prepare a fresh seniority list in accordance with law after adjusting the recruitment for the period 1951 to 1956 and onwards in accordance with the quota rule...
holdings.reasoning_summary: Same reasons as appeal; applies holdings on rules and quota to writ under Art 32.

holdings.text: We should also like to suggest to the Government that for future years the roster system should be adopted by framing an appropriate rule for working out the quota between the direct recruits and the promotees and that a roster should be maintained indicating the order in which appointments are made by direct recruits and by promotion in accordance with the percentages fixed under the statutory rule for each method of recruitment.

anchor.surface_text: We should also like to suggest to the Government that for future years the roster system should be adopted by framing an appropriate rule for working out the quota between the direct recruits and the promotees and that a roster should be maintained indicating the order in which appointments are made by direct recruits and by promotion in accordance with the percentages fixed under the statutory rule for each method of recruitment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suggestion to prevent future excesses via roster for quota implementation.

precedents.citation: The General Manager, Southern Railway v. Rangachari 1 ... 1962 2 S.C.R. 586, 596-598.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with the extent of protection of Art. 16 1  of the Constitution, this Court observed in The General Manager, Southern Railway v. Rangachari 1  It would be clear that matters relating to employment cannot be confined only to the initial matters prior to the act of employment. The narrow construction would confine the application of Art. 16  1  to the initial employment and nothing else but that clearly is only one of the matters relating to employment. The other matters relating to employment may include promotion (and if the State has the power to prescribe the condition for promotion, that would also be a matter relating to employment).

precedents.case_name: General Manager, Southern Railway v. Rangachari
precedents.cited_proposition: Article 16(1) guarantees equality of opportunity in all matters relating to employment, including initial appointment, promotion, salary, increments, terms of leave, gratuity, pension, and age of superannuation.
precedents.cited_holding: What Art. 16 1  guarantees is equality of opportunity to all citizens in respect of all the matters relating to employment...

anchor.surface_text: Law has reached its finest moments, stated Douglas, J. United States v. Wunderlick 1 , when it has freed man from he unlimited discretion of some ruler Where discretion absolute, man has always suffered. It is in this sense that the rule of law may be said to be the sworn enemy of caprice.

precedents.cited_proposition: Law reaches its finest moments when it frees man from unlimited discretion; where discretion is absolute, man has always suffered.

anchor.surface_text: Discretion, as Lord Mansfield stated it in classic terms in the case of John Wilkes 2 , means sound discretion guided by law. It must be governed by rule, number by humour it must number be arbitrary, vague and fanciful.

precedents.cited_proposition: Discretion means sound discretion guided by law; it must be governed by rule, not by humour; it must not be arbitrary, vague or fanciful.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we allow this appeal in part and order that a writ in the nature of Mandamus should be granted to the appellant to the extent indicated above. There will be no order as to costs in this appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed in part; seniority rules and promotion rules upheld as constitutional; excess promotee recruitments beyond quota declared illegal; writ of mandamus directing preparation of fresh seniority list after quota adjustment for 1951-1956 and onwards; writ petition also allowed on same grounds.
directions: Respondents 1-3 to adjust seniority of appellant and similarly placed officers and prepare fresh seniority list per quota rule in letter dated October 18, 1951
Order not to affect permanent appointments as Assistant Commissioners of Income Tax but applies to provisional ones
Adopt roster system for future quota implementation between direct recruits and promotees

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the contention of the appellant as correct. In our opinion, it is not right to approach this problem as if it is a case of classification of one service into two classes for the purpose of promotion, and as the promotion rule operation to the disadvantage of one of the two classes. It is really a case of recruitment to the Service from two different sources and then adjustment of seniority between the recruits coming from the two sources.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no substance in the contention of the appellant. Once it is held that the rule of seniority enacted in rule 1 f iii is legally valid, the rule of promotion i.e., rule 4 of Ch. IX of the Central Board of Revenue Office Procedure Manual cannot be held to lead to any discrimination as between direct recruits and promotees. Rule 4 states that the prescribed minimum service for Class 1, Grade 11 Officer in the matter of promotion to Grade I of that Service is five years gazetted service including one year in Class 1, Grade 11.

For these reasons we allow this appeal in part and order that a writ in the nature of Mandamus should be granted to the appellant to the extent indicated above. There will be no order as to costs in this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that rule 1 f iv is based on a reasonable classification and does not offend the guarantee under Art. 14 or Art. 16 1 of the Constitution.

For these reasons we allow this appeal in part and order that a writ in the nature of Mandamus should be granted to the appellant to the extent indicated above. There will be no order as to costs in this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the argument of the Solicitor-General that the quota rule was- number legally binding on the Government. It is number-disputed that rule 4 of the- Income-tax Officers (Class 1, Grade II) Service Recruitment Rules is a statutory rule and there is a statutory duty cast on the Government under this rule to, determine the method or methods to be employed for the purpose of filling the vacancies and. the number of candidates to be recruited by each method.

For these reasons we allow this appeal in part and order that a writ in the nature of Mandamus should be granted to the appellant to the extent indicated above. There will be no order as to costs in this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: to the exigencies of the situation or to deviate from the quota, in any particular year, at its own will and pleasure. As we have already indicated,

edges.explanation: Finding of quota violations supports the holding granting mandamus to remedy the excess recruitment.

anchor.surface_text: to the exigencies of the situation or to deviate from the quota, in any particular year, at its own will and pleasure. As we have already indicated,

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that promotees from Class II, Grade III to Class 1, Grade II Service in excess of the prescribed quotas for each of the years 1951 to 1956 and onwards have been illegally promoted and the appellant is entitled to a writ in the nature of mandamus commanding respondents I to 3 to adjust the seniority of the appellant and other officers similarly placed like him and to prepare a fresh seniority list in accordance with law after adjusting the recruitment for the period 1951 to 1956 and onwards in accordance with the quota rule prescribed in the letter of the Government of India No. F. 24 2 -Admn. I.T./51 dated October 18, 1951.

For these reasons we allow this appeal in part and order that a writ in the nature of Mandamus should be granted to the appellant to the extent indicated above. There will be no order as to costs in this appeal.
